statement.text: Reversed vein bypass harvests and flips the vein so the competent valves don't obstruct arterial flow, accepting a size mismatch (small end at femoral) in exchange for technical simplicity and reliable valve incompetence.

explanation.intuition: Veins have one-way valves that prevent backflow. To use a vein as an artery bypass, you can simply flip it upside down - now arterial blood pushes the valves open instead of closed. The tradeoff is the small end is now at the big artery.
explanation.key_insight: Reversed vein is technically simpler than in situ (no valvulotome needed) and has similar patency. The size mismatch is accepted; some surgeons prefer a larger conduit at the distal anastomosis where it's most critical.
explanation.technical_details: Technique: harvest GSV, reverse orientation (small/distal end becomes proximal), tunnel to target, anastomose. Advantages: technically simple, no valvulotome, all side branches ligated at harvest. Disadvantages: size mismatch (small end at femoral, large end at tibial), more handling injury. Patency: equivalent to in situ in randomized trials. Orientation check: flow direction, identify marked end.

procedural_details.technique: Harvest vein, reverse orientation, tunnel, anastomose
procedural_details.patency: Equivalent to in situ in randomized trials

clinical_pearls: Patency equivalent to in situ in randomized trials
Technically simpler - good choice for many situations
Mark vein orientation during harvest to avoid confusion
